newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish KPW to examine Polifarb merger-term protest.
newsitem.headline: Polish KPW to examine Polifarb merger-term protest.

text.p: The Polish Securities Commission (KPW) will examine whether any law was broken concerning last week's shareholders meetings of Polifarb Cieszyn and Polifarb Wroclaw, which plan to merge, the KPW said.

KPW spokeswoman Beata Stelmach told Reuters on Tuesday that the commission received a letter on Friday from Wroclaw shareholders protesting the terms of the merger planned for mid-year, and that a decision could come as early as this week.

"It bothers us a little that there are shareholders who have certain doubts on the whole procedure that went on at the general shareholders meeting...so we decided to look into the matter," Stelmach said.

Last week Credit Suisse Asset Management, which manages the London-listed Central European Growth Fund, wrote a letter for the fund and other U.S. and U.K. Wroclaw shareholders, asking the commission to prevent Cieszyn's version of the merger.

Cieszyn shareholders last Monday approved a merger plan giving them 53.5 rather than 50 percent of the new firm by increasing a planned pre-merger bonus issue for Cieszyn shareholders to 6.375 from 2.98 million shares.
Wroclaw shareholders approved the merger last Tuesday but did not vote on Cieszyn's version of the plan.
Wroclaw officials have said a mutual shareholder, BIG, might dispute Cieszyn's version in court but that the merger was still likely to go through as a delay would cost both firms.
